text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
--Jordan said its citizen, Derar al-Karmi -- financial controller at the Marriott Hotel in Beirut -- has been released more than three weeks after he disappeared in Lebanon.
--The Lebanese government approved a 233 billion Lebanese pounds increase in proposed 1997 budget spending. It decided to cut subsidies to electricity consumers by 200 billion pounds.
--Hizbollah Secretary-General Nasrallah: We are in the opposition but we don't want a direct confrontation with the government.
--Maronite Patriarch Sfeir: New laws related to the media and political parties are causes of concern and can change the face of Lebanon.
--Lebanon's Shopping festival to start in February.
--Minister of Electricity Hobeika criticizes security men especially intelligence officers.
-Governor of the Bank of Lebanon says: Reserves at $4 billion at the end of 1996.
